title: Addendum To “Economists On Education”
summary:
Key ideas:
- The article fails to make it clear that economists are, in fact, in favor of school vouchers.
- Changing the headline of the article could produce exactly the opposite impression in readers' minds.
- The majority of economists are not convinced that school vouchers are a bad idea.
- Uncertainty in the results of the survey can be interpreted in different ways, leading to different conclusions.
- The article does not accurately represent the opinion of economists on school vouchers.

Key learnings:
- Interpreting data to draw biased conclusions can be misleading.
- Uncertainty in survey results can lead to misinterpretation.
- The wording of a survey question can have a significant impact on the results.

Key questions:
- What is the best way to present survey results without being misleading?
- How can we ensure that survey questions are worded in a non-biased way?
- What impact does uncertainty in survey results have on their interpretation and usefulness?
